column1: By Liz Hampton and Valerie Volcovici

HOUSTON/WASHINGTON The top executive at the company behind the embattled Dakota Access Pipeline has donated more than $100
column2: 000 to Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump since June
column3: according to campaign finance disclosure records.The donations by Kelcy Warren

column5: support the candidate seen by many as more likely to promote the U.S. oil and gas industry than his opponent
column6: Democrat Hillary Clinton.Warren donated $300 to the Trump campaign during the primaries
column8: 700 to Trump during the general election phase of the campaign
column9: for the maximum contribution allowed by a single individual during an election. He also gave $100
column11: a joint fundraising committee that includes the Trump campaign
column13: the Republican Party of Arkansas and the Connecticut Republican Party. The donations
column14: first reported by the British newspaper The Guardian
column15: were made before the U.S. government halted construction on a segment of Energy Transfer Partners' 1
column17: 770-km) Dakota Access Pipeline in early September following protests by Native American and environmental groups.

column1: The project
column2: which would move oil from the highly productive Bakken shale formation to the Midwest and Gulf Coast
column3: sparked violent clashes between security officers near the construction site and Native American tribe members and other protesters. Opponents have said the project will damage burial sites considered sacred to the Standing Rock Sioux tribe and pollute the area's drinking water. Warren has also given $66
column4: 800 to the Republication National Committee since Trump secured the nomination for the Nov. 8 election
column5: The Guardian reported.Trump has not yet taken a position on the Dakota Access Pipeline
column6: but supports the development of oil and gas and related infrastructure

column1: Asked about Trump's position on the Dakota Access Pipeline in a policy debate this week

column3: one of the candidate's main energy advisers
column4: declined to answer
column5: saying he did not want to get ahead of Trump.He added
column6: ""I'm not sure he (Trump) is aware of it.""

column1: If elected

column3: according to his campaign website. U.S. President Barack Obama rejected the proposed pipeline from Canada last November.Trump has holdings in Energy Transfer Partners and Phillips 66
column4: a joint owner of the Dakota Access Pipeline
column5: through mutual funds
column6: according to financial disclosure records.U.S. oil and gas industry workers have contributed slightly more to Clinton
column10: according to a Reuters review of federal campaign finance disclosures. (Reporting by Liz Hampton and Valerie Volcovici in Washington; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-young-voters-idUSKCN12Q1VN	Clinton leading among young voters
column2: Harvard poll finds	"

column1: BOSTON Democratic White House candidate Hillary Clinton is leading among likely voters aged 18 to 29
column2: according to a Harvard University opinion poll released on Wednesday.The former U.S. secretary of state had the support of 49 percent of likely voters
column3: ahead of Republican rival Donald Trump's 28 percent support
column4: a substantially wider lead than Democratic President Barack Obama had over Republican former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney at the same point in 2012.National polls of voters of all ages also show Clinton leading
column5: though by a substantially narrower margin.Some 14 percent of respondents said they planned to vote for Libertarian Gary Johnson
column6: with 5 percent supporting the Green Party's Jill Stein and 11 percent still undecided. More than one in three self-described Johnson voters said they were likely to change their minds before Election Day.

column1: A majority of respondents
column2: 51 percent
column3: described themselves as ""fearful"" about the future of America
column4: with just 14 percent of the 2
column5: 150 respondents saying they believed the country was headed in the right direction.The sense of fearfulness was most predominant among white respondents
column6: though 85 of black respondents said they believed they were ""under attack"" in modern American society.

column1: Some 62 percent of respondents said they believed race relations in the United States would worsen if Trump was elected president. Twenty-two percent thought race relations would deteriorate if Clinton won the Nov. 8 election
column2: with the plurality
column3: 36 percent predicting they would stay the same.

column1: The survey
column2: conducted Oct. 7-17 has a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points
column3: meaning results could vary that much either way. (Reporting by Scott Malone; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-legislatures-idUSKCN12Q2MQ	Republican hold on U.S. state legislatures could slip in election	"
By Karen Pierog
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO The Republican Party's grip on U.S. state legislatures could loosen in next month's election as Democrats seek to link Republican candidates to the sinking fortunes of the party's White House candidate
column2: Donald Trump.Republicans
column3: who have dominated control of legislatures since the mid-term election in 2010
column4: currently hold the majority in 67 of the country's 98 partisan legislative chambers
column5: while Democrats have 31. Nebraska's single chamber is nonpartisan.More than 80 percent of the nation's 7
column6: 383 state legislative seats are up for grabs on Nov. 8 and the race between Trump and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton is expected to influence races further down the ballot papers. (See related graphic tmsnrt.rs/2ePmLDI)The bipartisan National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL) estimates 18 legislative chambers in 12 states could switch party control
column12: Washington and Wisconsin.""More than three-fourths of the time the party winning the White House also makes gains in state legislatures. So the odds are Democrats would pick up chambers and seats on the whole if (Clinton) wins
column14: a NCSL elections analyst.National opinion polls show Clinton leading Trump with just under two weeks to go until Election Day.Democrats are also getting a big boost for down ballot races with Clinton surrogates such as President Barack Obama
column16: and first lady Michelle Obama on the campaign trail stumping for party candidates. Trump
column18: is openly feuding with Republican leaders
column19: many of whom distanced themselves from the candidate after a 2005 video surfaced earlier this month in which he is heard bragging about groping women and making other unwanted sexual advances.Storey said while Trump has his pockets of popularity
column20: the top Republican on the party's ticket has become a main line of attack by Democrats in swing districts.

column1: Instead of taxes or health care or public safety or education
column2: Trump has been an issue in many places
column3: he said.According to Jessica Post
column4: executive director of the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee (DLCC)
column5: which is working to elect Democratic state lawmakers
column6: ""Trump is quicksand for legislative Republicans.""But Matt Walter
column7: president of the Republican State Leadership Committee (RSLC)
column8: which hopes to spend $40 million on legislative and other state races this election cycle
column9: said the Democrats' strategy of using Trump to campaign against Republicans is not working. He contended his party's candidates can win even without presidential coattails.""A good candidate who understands her district
column10: who presents viable solutions for that district in that state has a better than even odds of winning in any type of environment

column1: REPUBLICANS TRY OFFENSE
In addition to defending legislative turf

column4: including Illinois
column5: Iowa
column8: Colorado and Oregon.Post said Democratic candidates are offering voters ""a crucial firewall against Republican overreach"" in states dominated by Republicans
column10: where there has been a backlash against a law on use of public bathrooms that critics say discriminates against transgender people.  With all of Minnesota's legislative seats up for election
column11: Democrats need a net gain of seven seats to take control of the House and turn the state

column5: his wife and two of his wealthiest donors have contributed a combined $18 million since the March primary to House Republican leader Jim Durkin and to a super-PAC devoted to chipping away at Democrats' veto-proof majorities in the state's House and Senate.Democrats have been in a political stalemate with Rauner for nearly two years over the budget and other issues.In West Virginia

column9: and governor's office in 2014 for the first time in 83 years. This election

column13: West Virginia-based government affairs public relations firm
column14: said the likely scenario is the Senate remains Republican
column15: with much of the power ceded to a growing fiscally conservative faction.""Moderate Republicans are in trouble

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-clapper-idUSKCN12P2L7	Getting North Korea to give up nuclear bomb probably 'lost cause': U.S. spy chief	"
By David Brunnstrom
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. policy of trying to persuade North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons ""is probably a lost cause"" and the best that could be hoped for is a cap on the country's nuclear capability
column2: the Director of U.S. National Intelligence James Clapper said on Tuesday.However
column3: underscoring conflicting views in the Obama administration
column4: the State Department said U.S. policy was unchanged and continued to be to seek the ""verifiable denuclearization"" of the Korean peninsula.President Barack Obama has repeatedly stated that the United States will never accept North Korean as a nuclear-armed state.Clapper made clear at an event at the Council on Foreign Relations think tank in New York he did not think that the policy the administration has stuck to
column5: in spite of repeated North Korean nuclear tests
column6: was realistic.""I think the notion of getting the North Koreans to denuclearize is probably a lost cause
column7: Clapper said at the  Council on Foreign Relations think tank in New York. ""They are not going to do that - that is their ticket to survival.""Pyongyang has persisted with its missile and nuclear weapons programs
column9: despite strong international sanctions.Clapper said he got a good taste of how the world looks from North Korea's viewpoint when he went to Pyongyang on a mission in 2014 to secure the release of two Americans.""They are under siege and they are very paranoid
column10: so the notion of giving up their nuclear capability

column1: The best we could probably hope for is some sort of a cap
column2: but they are not going to do that just because we ask them. There's going to have to be some significant inducements.""CHINA PRESSES NEED TO TALK

column1: U.S. State Department spokesman John Kirby said he had not seen Clapper's remarks but told a regular news briefing in Washington that the administration did not believe denuclearization was a lost cause.
No
column2: nothing's changed ... that's not our position. Our policy objective is to seek to obtain a verifiable denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. That is the policy; that is both the goal and what we want to see and there is a way to do that.""Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang
column3: asked on Wednesday about Clapper's remarks
column4: said the best way to resolve the North Korea nuclear issue was still via talks.China and Russia have pushed for a resumption of six-party talks on denuclearization in North Korea. The talks
column5: which also involve Japan
column6: South Korea and the United States
column7: have been on hold since 2008.Clapper also said it bothered him that the United States was not capitalizing on using information as a weapon against North Korea.

column1: That's something they worry about a lot ... That is a great vulnerability I don't think we have exploited. Right now
column2: we are kind of stuck on our narrative and they are kind of stuck on theirs.""Clapper was asked if he thought North Korea could mount a nuclear warhead on a missile that could reach the West Coast of the United States and reiterated the intelligence assessment that this had to be a ""worst-case assumption.""He said North Korea had yet to test its KN08 intercontinental ballistic missile
column3: so neither North Korea nor the United States knew whether it worked.""Nevertheless
column4: we ascribe to them the capability to launch a missile that would have a weapon on it to reach parts of the United States
column5: certainly including Alaska and Hawaii
column6: he said.""They could do it. We have to make the worst-case assumption here."" (Reporting by David Brunnstrom
column7: Eric Walsh and David Alexander; Additional reporting by Ben Blanchard in Beijing; Editing by James Dalgleish

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-obama-idUSKCN12P2RV	Trump: Obama should be investigated over Clinton email server	"
By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| DORAL
column2: Fla./WASHINGTON

column1: DORAL
column2: Fla./WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Tuesday that President Barack Obama should be investigated over a private email server Hillary Clinton used while secretary of state
column3: saying Obama ""knew all about"" her email arrangements.""That's why he stuck up for Hillary
column4: because he didn't want to be dragged in. Because he knew all about her private server
column5: Trump said of the Democratic president in an interview with Reuters. ""This means that he has to be investigated.""The White House declined to comment on Trump's allegations. Spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters earlier on Tuesday that while the president had Clinton's personal email address
column6: which she used instead of government systems
column7: he did not know where her server was located or other details.Clinton
column8: Trump's Democratic rival in the Nov. 8 election
column9: was Obama's first secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.

column1: WikiLeaks on Tuesday released a batch of hacked emails from the account of Clinton's campaign manager
column2: John Podesta
column3: which showed her Democratic presidential campaign reacting after Obama said in a television interview that he learned of the private email server through news reports. ""We need to clean this up - he has emails from her - they do not say state.gov
column4: Cheryl Mills
column5: a longtime Clinton aide
column6: wrote in an email to Podesta after Obama made the comments in a March 2015 television interview. ""State.gov"" is the State Department's internet domain name
column7: and its presence in the sender's email address would indicate it came from an official account.The State Department said in January it found 18 instances  of messages between Clinton and Obama among the roughly 30
column8: 000 work emails Clinton returned to the department in 2014. None have been released because of a law that protects presidential communications from becoming public for several years.

column1: WikiLeaks has been releasing hacked emails in chunks for several weeks
column2: but the Clinton campaign has not officially confirmed their legitimacy.U.S. officials have said they believe Russia is behind recent hacks of Democratic Party systems
column3: and reports have indicated the theft of Podesta's emails may be related.

column1: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said his country is not to blame.Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey in July said Clinton was ""extremely careless"" with her emails but that no ""reasonable"" prosecutor would bring charges. (Reporting by Steve Holland in Doral
column2: Florida; Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton in Los Angeles; Writing by Emily Stephenson; Editing by Peter Cooney and Jonathan Oatis)"
